fdd:description.p: The "Native" Digital Orthophoto Quadrangle (DOQ) format was developed by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) and used for orthorectified digital aerial photographs or satellite images generated by and for USGS from the late 1980s through 2006. The specification was finalized in 1996.

A DOQ is a digital image that has the properties of an orthographic projection, derived from a digitized perspective aerial photograph or other remotely sensed image data by differential rectification so that image displacements caused by camera tilt and terrain relief are removed. The DOQ combines the image characteristics of the original photograph with the georeferenced qualities of a map. Ground features are displayed in their true position, allowing for the direct measurement of distance, areas, angles, and positions.
DOQs are cast to the UTM projection and referenced to the NAD 27 or NAD 83 datum. DOQs may be black and white (B/W), natural color, or color-infrared (CIR) images.

Digital orthophoto and DOQ refer to both the 1-meter ground resolution quarter-quadrangle digital orthophoto (3.75- x 3.75-minutes in extent) and the one or two-meter ground resolution quadrangle digital orthophoto (7.5- x 7.5-minutes in extent). The acronym DOQQ is used for quarter-quadrangle orthophotos when the distinction from the quadrangle DOQ orthophotos is necessary. The native DOQ is formatted with an ASCII keyword header followed by a series of 8-bit binary image lines. Color DOQs are 24-bit band-interleaved-by-pixel (BIP) images. The header contains a wide range of data for identifying, displaying, and georeferencing the image. Digital orthophotos are also available from USGS in the GeoTIFF format, cast to the UTM projection and referenced to the NAD 83 datum. GeoTIFF DOQs consist of a georeferenced TIFF, with all geographic referencing information embedded within the .tif file.

Since an orthophoto shows features that may be omitted on maps, a DOQ can be used as a base image to assemble, review, and revise other data, especially digital line graphs (DLG) and topographic maps. When the DOQ is combined with other USGS digital products, such as digital raster graphics (DRG) or digital elevation models (DEM), the resulting image provides additional visual information for the extraction and revision of base cartographic information.

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: A digital image with the properties of an orthographic projection in a standard format developed by USGS (U.S. Geological Survey). It is derived from a digitized perspective aerial photograph or other remotely sensed image data. DOQs were produced by USGS between 1987 and 2006.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: DOQs are middle or final-state images, derived from source aerial or satellite photographs by orthorectification. DOQs are often used as a base image for other cartographic products.

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: Band Interleaved by Pixel (BIP) Image Encoding

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Openly accessible specification developed by USGS (U.S. Geological Survey).
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: Published by USGS at Digital Orthophoto Standards. "Standards for Digital Orthophotos" was published in 1996 as three documents: an introduction; Part 1: General; and Part 2: Specifications. No longer online as of May 2020. Links via Internet Archive.

fdd:adoption.p: In 2005, according to USGS Business Partner Program: Digital Cartographic Data, dealerships were available for the redistribution of three digital data product lines: digital elevation models (DEM), digital line graphs (DLG), and digital orthophoto quadrangles (DOQ).

DOQs were generated and distributed by many agencies in the U.S. Federal Government and by states. See National Digital Orthoimagery Program (NDOP) Data for a list of agencies and states that were offering orthoimagery data as of January 2013.
DOQs were incorporated into the National Map, usable as a base layer, until replaced by more recent imagery.

As of May 2020, the DOQ images, which were published through 2006, are treated as an archive. Individual DOQ images can be previewed through EarthExplorer (in the Aerial Imagery category) and through the USGS Global Visualization Viewer (GloVis). Requests for download can be placed.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: DOQs are distributed in compressed and uncompressed forms. The uncompressed form is more transparent and can be interpreted more easily with basic tools. Header information is in ASCII.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:selfDocumentation: The DOQ header contains information to support identification, georeferencing, and appropriate display, including date of creation, agency creating the DOQ, and details for source data from which the DOQ was derived.

fdd:filenameExtension.fdd:note: Various services identifying file types from extensions suggest that .doq is used as the extension for native DOQ files. This usage is a convention, not in the specification.

fdd:history.p: Orthophoto production began at the USGS Western Mapping Center (WMC) in Menlo Park, California (now called the Western Geographic Science Center), in 1965. The first USGS National Mapping Program Standard for Digital Orthophotos was released in 1992. Relatively small changes were made in 1993. In December 1996, a complete revision of both format and content of the DOQ header was issued, together with updated technical standards for imagery.

In 1997, the USGS Western Mapping Center (WMC) and Microsoft Corporation entered into a Cooperative Research and Development Agreement to make DOQs easily available to the public through the TerraServer USA Web site. This service was later incorporated into the National Map.

Since 2013, the DOQ images generated in the period 1987-2006 in the Native DOQ format have been treated as an archive. In May 2020, the archived DOQ dataset is described at the USGS EROS Archive. Previously, the archive was listed at the USGS Long Term Archive at lta.cr.usgs.gov.

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: Since 2013, the DOQ images generated in the period 1987-2006 in the Native DOQ format have been treated as an archive. As of May 2020, the images themselves are available through EarthExplorer (in the Aerial Imagery category) and the USGS Global Visualization Viewer (GloVis). Images can be located and previewed by any user; downloading images in the DOQ format (or as a GeoTIFF) at full resolution requires a user registration step. The archived dataset has a DOI as a persistent identifier and is described at the USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Archive. Previously, the archive was listed at the USGS Long Term Archive at lta.cr.usgs.gov.
